Award.AwardTitle: Nuclear Structure, Mesoscopic Physics and Double-Beta Decay
Award.AbstractNarration:
The elements observed on the earth and in our sun contain the most stable isotopes of nuclei. However, there are a great many other forms of these isotopes with greater or lesser numbers of neutrons that only exist for a short time. The formation of these unstable nuclei is essential for understanding the origin of the observed elements during astrophysics events such as supernovae explosions. This project in nuclear theory will contribute significantly to our understanding of the observed properties of stable and unstable nuclei and predicts properties that are not yet observed. This research quantifies the limits of nuclear stability and chains of formations and decays that are needed for understanding the formation of elements during the evolution of the universe. Nuclear decays are determined by the properties of the fundamental particles. The investigators will also study a form of double-beta decay in which no neutrinos are emitted and in which the mass of the neutrino may be determined. Furthermore, this project will advance computational and analytical methods in nuclear physics, and will add to an already rich computational program for nuclear structure that is being used worldwide.

Nuclear physics is at the heart of our understanding of the universe and the types of elementary particles with which it is composed. This project will have a significant impact on new developments in the field of nuclear theory, fundamental symmetries, nuclear astrophysics and the general field of mesoscopic physics. Topics to be studied include: (1) development of new analytical and computational tools for the description of nuclear structure (2) detailed theoretical studies of nuclear processes affecting unstable nuclei; (iii) calculations and modeling of structural and dynamical aspects of nuclear processes, including reactions of astrophysical interest; (iv) calculations of nuclear properties related to fundamental symmetries and double-beta decay; (v) development of the unified description of structure and reactions in open and marginally stable mesoscopic systems and quantum transport in problems of interest to quantum informatics; (vi) studies of the nucleus as a mesoscopic system, including many-body quantum chaos and its coexistence with collective and regular features. Many of these research topics are connected to the experimental programs at the National Superconducting Cyclotron Laboratory (NSCL) and other laboratories worldwide. This work is also closely coupled with the Joint Institute for Nuclear Astrophysics (JINA), and some projects bridge nuclear structure theory with other areas, such as condensed matter physics and quantum information. Strong educational and outreach component are integral components of this effort, as the nuclear physics program at MSU is widely recognized worldwide as a top program in this discipline.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research carried out during the time period for NSF grant PHY-1404442 related to broad questions in science. What are the limits of nuclear stability? How did the chemical evolution of the Universe proceed? What are the masses of the neutrinos? How do the nuclear properties emerge from the underlying nucleon-nucleon interactions? How does order coexist with chaos and complexity in quantum mesoscopic systems? We developed new analytical and computational tools for the description of nuclear structure, especially for the nuclei far from stability and for the aspects related to nuclear astrophysics. We collaborated with the experimental groups at the National Superconducting Cyclotron Laboratory to help guide proposed experiments, and to understand the outcomes in a historical context and as a guide to the improvements needed in nuclear theory. We developed computational tools for configuration-interaction and energy-density functional calculations and provided these to other theoretical and experimental groups. We provided help with the use of these theorteical tools, for example, at the 2017 TALANT Course 5 on "Theory for Exploring Nuclear Structure Experiments" held at the European Center for Theoretical Nuclear Physics and Related Areas, Trento in July 21 of 2017.

This grant supported graduate students Adam Jones and Aaron Magilligan at MSU, and Shiplu Sarker and Fahim Ahmed at CMU, and a Research Associate, Sofia Karampagia, at MSU. In addition our work was carried out with students in the MSU summer High School Honors program (currently undergraduates of prestigious universities) and those in the MSU summer Research Experience for Undergraduates program . We also worked with the graduate student Amin Tayebi who obtained a dual degree in Physics and Enginerring.  Our work with students resulted in many publications.

Many of the projects were connected to the Physics Frontier Center JINA-CEE (Joint Institute for Nuclear Astrophysics Center for the Evolution of the Elements) centered at MSU. We calculated rapid proton rates for X-ray bursters, beta decay and electron capture rates for supernovae, and used nuclear data to constrain the neutron equation of state needed to model neutron stars and neutron star mergers.

One of the questions investigated during the period funded by this award is: what is the nature of neutrino, and how this relates to the theory of “almost” everything, which is the Standard Model of the physics of elementary particles and of their interactions. Neutrinos are part of the standard model and were originally assumed to be massless. More recently, neutrino oscillation experiments indicated that neutrinos have a feeble mass, and that the neutrinos we observe are mixtures of more basic neutrinos. This was the first indication that the physics beyond the Standard Model may exist. There are many ways of describing the masses of neutrinos and their mixing, and the present data does not yet provide a definitive solution. One of the main problems that remain unresolved is if neutrinos are their own antiparticles or not. The nuclear double beta decay of some isotopes, a very rare process, could answer that question, and then bring the community closer to a resolution regarding the extension of the Standard Model required by the novel properties of the neutrinos. Our group studied the double beta decay process from many possible points of view, and we calculated the necessary nuclear matrix elements for the analysis of the experimental data. The results of our calculation are also very useful for planning these expensive and time consuming double beta decay experiments, or for extracting experimental constraints of the needed nuclear matrix elements.

The mesoscopic world – intermediate between the microscopic and macroscopic – currently attracts efforts of physicists and engineers.  This is a world of small systems of many strongly interacting elements that includes solid state devices on the nano-scale, atomic clusters, complex atoms and molecules (including biological), complex nuclei, and structures for modern computers (in the future quantum). Nuclear theory is well suited for solving such problems. One of the important questions is the nuclear level density as a function of excitation energy. It determines the output of nuclear reactions, in the laboratory, in nuclear plants and in cosmos. The behavior of the level density was studied in detail as a function of nuclear characteristics (numbers of protons and neutrons, nuclear spins, various types of interactions). The result is the prediction of the level density in many nuclei and recommendations for the parameters to be used in experimental applications.Exotic (loosely bound) nuclei are studied at the NSCL and FRIB facilities at Michigan State University. The nuclear reactions here have many common features with the quantum signal transmission through many natural and artificial systems. The nuclear knowledge was adjusted for such problems which include the propagation of a signal through a periodic chain with an included qubit (the unit of quantum computation). With this arrangement it is possible to regulate the lifetime of the qubit.
